Headline.Para: Recent Aussie polls reflect resistance to global populist tide

Snippet.Para: Observers say minor parties are unlikely to dislodge the major ones any time soon
Populist parties and leaders have been gaining ground across the world in recent years, but Australia is emerging as something of an anomaly.

ReplyItem.Byline: Jonathan PearlmanFor The Straits Times In Sydney

Headline.Para: Recent Aussie polls reflect resistance to global populist tide

LeadPara.Para: Observers say minor parties are unlikely to dislodge the major ones any time soon
Populist parties and leaders have been gaining ground across the world in recent years, but Australia is emerging as something of an anomaly.

TailParas.Para: At a series of recent elections - including a state poll and a federal by-election earlier this month - smaller parties recorded disappointing results and Australian voters appeared to be shifting towards the reliable centre.

Despite a gradual, 25-year drop in overall support for the two main party blocs - the right-of-centre Liberal-National Coalition and the left-of-centre Labor party - opinion surveys show their hold on power is not under threat from populist or minor parties.

In the state of South Australia, a new party headed by a popular former federal MP and self-described "agitator", Mr Nick Xenophon, had a disappointing result at an election earlier this month. Some analysts had predicted that his SA Best party could topple the major parties.

But SA Best failed to secure a seat in the 47-member Lower House and won only 14 per cent of the primary vote, compared with 37 per cent for the Liberal party and 34 per cent for Labor. The party fared better in the Upper House, winning 19 per cent.
Separately, in a federal by-election in the Melbourne inner-city seat of Batman, Labor won comfortably despite expectations that the Greens would clinch a victory.
Earlier this month, at a state election in Tasmania, the Greens went from five seats to two - and a party led by a populist-style former federal MP, Ms Jacqui Lambie, failed to win a seat.

Analysts said the results indicated that Australia was resisting the populist tide that had affected recent ballots worldwide, including the United States presidential election and the British referendum vote to leave the European Union.

An expert on Australian politics, Professor John Warhurst from the Australian National University, noted that Australia appeared to have resisted the populist trend that had affected numerous countries, particularly since the 2008 global financial crisis.
"Maybe there was a feeling after Brexit and Trump that these groups would sail in on the high tide and absolutely smash the major parties," he told The Straits Times.
"That has not happened."

He said that Australia's strong economy and the stability of its major political parties probably helped to prevent a populist surge. With Australia's tough approach on asylum seekers arriving by boat, he said, the nation had not been affected by a recent wave of mass immigration.

"Australian society has not been destabilised in the same way as some of the immigration trends have affected parts of Europe," said Prof Warhurst. "The Australian economy has done reasonably well through the global financial crisis. There is certainly a lot of unfairness and inequality but, compared with the other counties, there has not been the same sort of fracturing of the economy."
Analysts said that the failure of Mr Xenophon's party - which blends centrism and populism - was due to either his party's lack of readiness or policy detail.
Similar problems have also bedevilled Ms Pauline Hanson's anti-migrant and anti-Islam One Nation party, even though it has a very different political agenda.

Political commentator Peter van Onselen, from the University of Western Australia, said minor parties in Australia have been struggling to record more than a "protest vote", even though the public is not particularly happy with the performance of the major parties.
He said the political system favoured major parties, noting that Australia's compulsory voting prevents minor parties or populists from capitalising on low voter turnouts.
"The system and our political culture isn't accommodating of minor parties rising to challenge the majors in any sustainable way," he wrote in The Australian last Tuesday.
But smaller parties are still having an observable effect.
At a federal level, they hold the balance of power in the Upper House, and the Greens could yet win numerous Lower House seats in the inner cities of Sydney and Melbourne.
The major parties have also been forced to shift their positions on issues such as climate change, banking policy and immigration to stave off a potential loss of votes to smaller parties.

Commentators pointed out that the minor parties have failed to live up to expectations and are unlikely to dislodge the Coalition or Labor from power any time soon - but they are still growing slowly.
The ABC's election analyst, Mr Antony Green, said support for the major parties has been declining for 25 years.

"Support for the non-major parties is yet to coalesce around a new political force," he told ABC News yesterday . "It still tends to be for independents, for minor parties based around individuals, and it tends to be spread very thinly."

Article.Byline: Jonathan PearlmanFor The Straits Times In Sydney
Article.Art: In recent polls in South Australia, Mr Nick Xenophon's SA Best party failed to secure a seat in the Lower House and won only 14 per cent of the primary vote. Analysts say the failure of his party was due to lack of readiness or policy detail.
